title: Pointing Pairs
description: When a candidate within a box is restricted to a single row or column, it can be eliminated elsewhere in that line.

steps.title: What are Pointing Pairs?
steps.content: A Pointing Pair (or Pointing Triple) occurs when all candidates for a particular digit within a box are confined to a single row or column. Since the digit must go somewhere in that box, and all options are in one line, the digit can be eliminated from that line outside the box.

steps.title: Look inside a box
steps.content: Consider the left-center box. Most cells are filled. The digit 6 is missing from this box — let's find where it can go.

steps.title: The candidates point along a row
steps.content: Only two cells in the box are empty, and both are in the same row (row 4). The digit 6 must go in one of these two cells. They 'point' along the row, telling us something about cells outside the box.

steps.title: Eliminate along the row
steps.content: Since 6 must go in one of these two cells (both in row 4, both in this box), 6 cannot appear elsewhere in row 4. Remove 6 as a candidate from all other cells in the row that are outside the box.

steps.title: Pointing along columns
steps.content: The same logic works for columns. If a digit's candidates within a box all fall in one column, eliminate that digit from the rest of the column outside the box.

steps.title: Pointing Triples
steps.content: If the candidate appears in three cells within the box (all in the same row or column), it's called a Pointing Triple. The elimination logic is identical — remove the digit from the rest of that line.

steps.title: How to search systematically
steps.content: For each box, check each digit 1–9. Count which cells in the box have that digit as a candidate. If all of them are in one row (or column), you have a Pointing Pair/Triple. Then check if there's anything to eliminate in the rest of that line.

steps.title: Key insight
steps.content: Pointing Pairs link box logic with line logic. They're one of the most common intermediate techniques and often unlock cells that single-based techniques can't reach.
